lessonOverview.title: Unit 4 - Lesson 2
structures: B: Yes, I do. / No, I don’t.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six zoo animals (monkeys, bears, elephants, lions, zebras, giraffes) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Use zoo animal images. Say: “This is a zebra.” Students repeat. Then play “Find the animal” in the SB or on the board.
stretchStrategies: Animal Survey Challenge: Students draw a 6-box table in their notebooks with each zoo animal name. They walk around the class asking, “Do you like ___?” and recording Yes/No answers from 5 classmates. Then they report back to the class: “Three students like lions. Two don’t like monkeys.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about zoo animals using "Do you like...?" and respond with "Yes, I do." / "No, I don't."
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Ask: “Do you like lions?” Students answer: “Yes, I do.” or “No, I don’t.” Use thumbs up/down gestures to reinforce.
stretchStrategies: Animal Survey Challenge: Students draw a 6-box table in their notebooks with each zoo animal name. They walk around the class asking, “Do you like ___?” and recording Yes/No answers from 5 classmates. Then they report back to the class: “Three students like lions. Two don’t like monkeys.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer questions using the target structure “Do you like...?” / “Yes, I do." / "No, I don't.” to talk about zoo animals.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write Q&A on board: “Do you like ___?” – “Yes, I do.” / “No, I don’t.” Students ask/answer in pairs using flashcards.

items: Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Bạn muốn ăn gì? >> you want to eat what? [what do you want to eat?]
This is extremely difficult to master, especially combined with do-support.

Phonics introduces each vowel with one sound, which quickly breaks down past the Kindergarten 2 level. Think of the es in elephant or the as in banana. This does not happen in Vietnamese, where every vowel is pronounced as written.
Bạn có thích ăn bánh mì không? >> you like eat bread? [do you like to eat bánh mì?]
